title: 113_s691
content: The Act titled "High-Capacity Ammunition Magazine Ban of 2013" defines a 'large capacity ammunition feeding device' as a device that can hold more than 10 rounds of ammunition. It excludes tubular devices for .22 caliber rimfire ammunition and provides restrictions on such devices. The High-Capacity Ammunition Magazine Ban of 2013 prohibits the import, sale, manufacture, transfer, or possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices in interstate or foreign commerce. Exceptions are made for devices lawfully possessed before the enactment date and for specific entities like the United States or law enforcement agencies. The curr_chunk discusses exceptions to the High-Capacity Ammunition Magazine Ban of 2013, allowing transfer or possession by qualified law enforcement officers for law enforcement purposes, importation for establishing security systems under the Atomic Energy Act, and possession by licensee employees for authorized purposes. The curr_chunk discusses exceptions to the High-Capacity Ammunition Magazine Ban of 2013, including possession by retired law enforcement officers, importation for testing purposes by licensed manufacturers, and authorized possession by licensee employees. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a campus law enforcement officer, including their responsibilities and qualifications. Additionally, it mentions the identification markings for large capacity ammunition feeding devices. The curr_chunk discusses the requirement for large capacity ammunition feeding devices to have a serial number and manufacturing date engraved on them. Additionally, it amends the seizure and forfeiture regulations for such devices in the United States Code. The curr_chunk amends regulations by inserting references to large capacity ammunition feeding devices in specific paragraphs of the United States Code. The curr_chunk amends penalties under title 18, United States Code, and allows the use of Byrne grants for buy-back programs for large capacity ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 6. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or its amendments is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments remain unaffected.
